Executive Summary
DHL Supply Chain is a large company that is a global leader in logistics and provides supply
chain management services. The company specializes in warehousing, transportation, and
distribution, focusing on services that meet the specific needs of various industries.
Engineering activities include optimizing supply chain operations, implementing advanced
technology for automation and effective warehouse management to increase efficiency and
ensure customer satisfaction. During my internship at DHL Supply Chain Warehouse 8, I had
the chance to experience the logistics and supply chain sector in all its details. I was in
assignments where I could gain practical knowledge starting from the very basics. My basic
responsibilities and what I learned were as follows:
- Order Picking: I tried to identify inefficiencies by experiencing the current order picking
processes one-on-one under the leadership of team leaders. During this process, I thought
and focused more on reducing the travel time of order pickers.
- Warehouse Layout Planning: I focused on the question of how to make picking methods
easier based on the order frequency of the products and I did a reading and reinforcement
study on this subject. I dealt with the mapping of the physical layout of the shelves and
making them interpretable on Excel.
-Data Analysis: I worked on collecting and analyzing data on order processing and
warehouse density levels. I also made manual measurements during the data collection
process to have understanding my project better. The data was used for operational
improvements. I did all these things on Excel.
- Project Participation: I took part in a project for the integration of a new Warehouse
Management System (WMS). (This project is also the project I had to develop during my
internship.) My task was to briefly analyze the current storage and product collection
processes, comment on their shortcomings, and then contribute to making them more
efficient with feedback.
My expectation from my internship is to hands-on experience in supply chain management
and understand what industrial engineers do in this sector. I was hoping to learn the daily
operations of a logistics company and apply the knowledge I learned to contribute to real-
world projects. My expectations were more than met throughout the internship. I had the
opportunity to learn this industry in the best way I could. Therefore, I would like to thank
everyone who helped me in Warehouse 8.
In 20 working days, I learned a lot, both in terms of knowledge and practical skills:
- How warehouse operations are run in a logistics company.
- The importance of efficient order picking.
- How to analyze and usage of the data to improve all operations.
- The importance of warehouse organization to improve flows and reduce waste.
- What happens during the transition to new applications.
This experience significantly broadened my perspective on supply chain management and
logistics, which was almost zero. It also improved my problem-solving skills and my ability to
work collaboratively in a professional environment. And most importantly for me, it instilled
in me how to think as an industrial engineer. It increased my interest in my department and
my enthusiasm for work.
Figure 1: DHL Logo

1. Company and Sector
a. Overview of the Company and Sector
DHL Supply Chain is a division of Deutsche Post DHL Group. The origins of Deutsche Post DHL
Group date back to 1969 and began with DHL, founded by Adrian Dalsey, Larry Hillblom and
Robert Lynn. DHL takes its name from the first letters of the surnames of these three
founders. Initially offering international air express services and document delivery services,
DHL has expanded into freight forwarding, logistics and supply chain management. In 2005,
Deutsche Post acquired Exel plc, a leading logistics company based in the UK, and this
acquisition expanded DHL Supply Chain's global footprint and services. Its global network
serves multinational companies with complex supply chain needs, as well as providing
tailored logistics solutions to regional and local businesses. DHL Supply Chain operates in
more than 60 countries around the world, with 2,400 locations, 120,000 logistics experts
and 23 million m2 of storage space. It provides warehousing, distribution and distribution
network management services, as well as value-added services such as labeling and
packaging in the automotive, consumer, retail, technology, healthcare and industrial sectors.
In Turkey, it started operating in the field of supply chain and logistics solutions in 2000.
With a total of more than 1700 employees and a storage area exceeding 370 thousand m2,
it offers services such as labeling, packaging, home delivery, spare parts logistics and reverse
logistics in addition to storage and distribution services to leading companies in the
consumer, retail, health, automotive, industrial production and technology sectors. In Gebze
Warehouse 8, it provides services in a 29,404 square meter warehouse. Of the 228
employees, 120 are full-time warehouse personnel and 3 are industrial engineers.
Warehouse 8, which has 27 loading and unloading docks and a pallet capacity of 34,500
units, has a height of 11.7 meters. There is three largest customers these are Mondelez
International, Nestle and Mars.Optimizing logistics and supply chain management is critical
to reducing costs, shortening delivery times, and increasing customer satisfaction by
ensuring the efficient delivery of goods and services from suppliers to customers. This sector
integrates various activities such as procurement, production, warehousing, transportation,
distribution, and reverse logistics (product returns and recycling). In addition to DHL Supply
Chain, other major global players such as UPS Supply Chain Solutions, FedEx Supply Chain,
Kuehne + Nagel, and CEVA Logistics play important roles in this field. There are also regional
companies in the sector that focus on specific geographic regions or specialize in little
markets. Digitalization and sustainability are two important trends in logistics and supply
chain management. While the adoption of digital technologies such as IoT, artificial
intelligence, and blockchain are used to increase visibility, predict processes, and optimize
supply chain operations; the interest in sustainability initiatives, which are very important in
today's world, such as reducing carbon footprint, optimizing transportation routes, and
adopting environmentally friendly packaging materials in line with environmental concerns,
is increasing day by day. As a result, DHL Supply Chain and the broader logistics and supply
chain industry enable the efficient movement of goods and services across complex supply
networks to support global trade and economic activity. Technological advances and market
dynamics continue to shape the future of global logistics and supply chain management.

b. Organization of the Company
At the highest level, there is the Warehouse Manager. The Warehouse Manager assumes
general responsibility for warehouse operations, makes strategic plans, manages customer
relations and is responsible for general management. At the middle management level,
there is the Operations Manager and the Logistics Manager. There are currently 2
operations in Warehouse 8, one is Nestle and the other is Mondelez. The part where I did
my internship is the Mondelez part. The Operations Manager is the person I work with and is
responsible for the management of daily operations on behalf of the Mondelez department,
ensuring that all processes in the warehouse are carried out efficiently. In the logistics part,
he manages the goods receiving, inventory management, shipping and distribution
processes. In the lower management level, that is, when we look inside the warehouse,
there is the Shift Supervisor, Quality Control Supervisor and Inventory Control Supervisor.
The Shift Supervisor supervises the warehouse operations throughout the shift and ensures
that the employees fulfill their duties. There are 3 shifts for DHL Gebze Warehouse 8. The
Quality Control Officer checks the compliance of the products with quality standards and
audits the quality management processes. I learned information about the system section
from the employees in this section on the 3rd day of my internship.
The work units that I call the basic section are this section. The operation teams that
observed all the operation details and helped me think about improvements on the 6th day
of my internship are the Receiving Team, Storage Team, Order Picking Team and Shipping
Team, and they work in the background of the logistics and storage processes. The Receiving
Team performs the acceptance and entry processes of the products arriving at the

c. Production/Service System
Production/Service System
Operations at DHL Supply Chain are based on a highly interconnected service system. At the
heart of this system are warehouse management and logistics processes, which are critical
to Mondelez's supply chain. Processes such as goods receipt, inventory management, order
preparation and shipping constitute the basic components of the service. In order to
successfully manage these processes, continuous coordination is ensured with departments
such as logistics operations, financial planning, purchasing, customer relations and human
resources.
Relationship with Marketing
The effectiveness of the services provided by DHL Supply Chain is of great importance in
terms of increasing customer satisfaction. Working with a large customer such as Mondelez
in particular requires speed, efficiency and accuracy of logistics processes. The marketing
team strengthens the brand value by conveying to customers the information that the
operations are carried out on time and completely. In this context, the successes achieved in
logistics processes directly contribute to marketing strategies.
Relationship with Production
All operations carried out in the warehouse begin with the transfer of products from
Mondelez's production lines to the warehouses. Production planning and forecasting help
determine storage capacity and shipment frequency.According to the integration between
production and logistics processes ensures effective management of stocks and plays a
critical role in responding quickly to customer demands.
Relationship with Finance
The management of logistics operations is carried out in close relationship with the finance
department in terms of minimizing costs and efficient use of resources. Shelf arrangements
within the warehouse can contribute to reducing operational costs. The shelf layout changes
you suggest are valuable in terms of both time and cost savings by allowing areas close to
product collection points to be used more frequently.

Flow and Process
Figure 7: Basic process chart
7

Goods Receiving: Products coming from the production line are received by the goods
receiving team. During this process, products are counted, quality controlled and defined as
stock in the system. Quality control processes are a critical step to increase customer
satisfaction.
Storage: Accepted products are placed in storage areas according to product categories and
order density. The warehouse map you created in Excel during your internship clearly
showed how products are positioned and potential areas for improvement in this process.
Order Preparation: As orders arrive, the order preparation team picks and prepares the
products for shipment. Especially during busy periods, optimizing the collection points is of
great importance at this stage. According to your observations, placing the products in
appropriate places can speed up the order preparation process.
Shipping: The collected products are sent to the customer locations by the shipping team.
Fast and accurate management of the shipping process plays a critical role in increasing
customer satisfaction.
Figure 8: Detailed process chart
Productive and Non-Productive Elements
Productive Elements: Order preparation, picking and shipping processes stand out as
productive elements that directly serve customer demands.
Non-Productive Elements: Processes such as product movements within the warehouse and
stock controls are among the non-productive but necessary support elements for the
smooth progress of operational processes. Improving these processes is important to
increase overall efficiency.
Performance Details
Stock Turnover Rate: How long it takes for products to be sold and restocked is an important
indicator that measures the efficiency of logistics processes. In your analysis, high sales
volumes and order increases during busy periods are the factors that affect this turnover
rate.
8

Shelf System: A new racking system can help speed up the shipping process by reducing
picking time. The data you get from conditional formatting shows how necessary this
improvement process is.

d. Professional and Ethical Responsibilities of Engineers
My observations during my internship confirmed how important the professional and ethical
responsibilities of industrial engineers in this company are. First of all, there were 2
industrial engineers that I closely observed, including Mehmet Bey, the manager of the
department where I did my internship. The ethical part is very important, especially in terms
of efficient and sustainable progress in the operations section and ensuring the motivational
and quantitative efficiency of the departments. Industrial Engineers are responsible for
analyzing every step in the logistics processes. In particular, the optimization of the
warehouse layout and product collection processes is one of the issues that engineers
constantly think about. As in the current warehouse layout, placing large-volume and high-
weight products in the most easily accessible places gives positive momentum to the order
preparation process. They are responsible for evaluating the operations using various
efficiency indicators and monitoring them. This responsibility is called OMS within DHL
Supply Chain, and Raşit Ömer Bey, whom I was able to observe in this regard, was a very
successful engineer. For example, the collection times of the products in the warehouse, the
accuracy of the shipping processes and the speed of the goods acceptance processes, the
work performances of the blue-collar workers in the warehouse are analyzed and awards
are given according to these performances in certain periods. DHL is a company that
attaches great importance to digitalization and technological solutions, and as far as I know,
gives consultancy is also provided on the company. Industrial engineers, warehouse
management systems (WMS) and automation technologies are the most emphasized
subjects in terms of faster and more efficient operation. At the same time, they take an
active role in inventory management processes and prevent shortages or excess stocks by
monitoring stock levels. They make communication with customers healthier by making
demand forecasts and contribute to the smooth progress of shipping programs.
Professional and Ethical Responsibilities of Industrial Engineers
The ethical part is very important, especially in logistics operations in the food sector
(Mondelez operations include leading brands in the food sector such as Milka, First, etc.).
Even the smallest detail (for example, a 0.7 degree drop in temperature) can negatively
affect many things in operations. In this case, it is about the correct use of data and the
reporting process. Honest reports are important for the company's overall performance and
customer satisfaction. Not providing misleading or incomplete information is the best
approach at this point.
Occupational Safety and Employee Welfare is perhaps the riskiest part of ethical
responsibilities. The health and safety of employees should be at the forefront in every
matter. Control should be provided for people working under difficult conditions such as
operations in the warehouse, and occupational health and safety equipment should be
checked and updated at certain intervals. During the 1 week that I observed in the
warehouse, I observed firsthand that this was given great importance at DHL and that no
concessions were made to anyone in this regard. The section at the company entrance
showing the number of days without a work accident can be considered a source of
motivation for both blue-collar and white-collar employees. Preventing work accidents and
creating ergonomic working conditions in warehouses is both a professional and ethical
responsibility.
9

If I were to classify ethical rules under three headings, the three headings that I was most
interested in and happy to observe at DHL were as follows.
Fair and Equal Working Environment: I observed that coworkers and lower-level employees
were treated in accordance with this principle of justice and equality and that there was a
very healthy motivation in terms of communication. An area where everyone was happy was
created.
Confidentiality and Reliability: Engineers working at DHL are obliged to keep the company's
trade secrets and customer data confidential. Examples of this are that no photos are taken
in the warehouse, each product has separate codes and not everyone can access these
codes, the IT department works meticulously and the warehouse is not entered without
permission.
Contribution to Society and the Environment: The company expects engineers to act with a
sense of social responsibility and clearly expresses this. It also attaches great importance to
the social life of its employees. The tournaments, workshops and awards they organized this
summer are examples of this. In this context, it is very important to develop environmentally
sensitive projects and they are open to all suggestions from employees who come up with
projects that contribute to sustainability goals and support development. Industrial
engineers not only manage technical processes in large logistics companies such as DHL, but
also act with business ethics and social responsibility awareness. They are also responsible
for setting an example for other employees.
Figure 9: Waste bins in the warehouse

2. Summer Practice Description
DHL Supply Chain 8. I had the chance to observe many things related to my department
during my internship at the warehouse. The things I observed were generally about analysis,
optimization and some operations.
I had a 1- week training and application process for the process analysis and optimization
part and during this process I observed everything about logistics. It was about monitoring
the flow from the warehouse to the shipment of products and how processes can be
optimized, what employees do, what they complain about and how solutions can be
produced.
- In the inventory management part, I matched the information I got from the book
WAREHOUSE & DISTRIBUTION SCIENCE that I read before starting my main job in my
10

internship, using the Warehouse Management System (WMS) to monitor stock levels and
how to analyze the frequency of product movements. I observed how shift employees
control this, which RF systems they use and even how they control the process with RF and
how these are processed in the SAP system.
- Quality control: Inspecting incoming products and documenting deviations in product
quality.
- Data analysis: Creating pivot tables using Excel and other tools, analyzing shipment data
and determining trends.
- Lean operations: Conducting studies on reducing waste in processes by observing the
implementation of lean production principles.
The tasks I performed were closely related to the operations research, manufacturing
systems, and probability and statistics courses I took in my department. For example,
process optimization and data analysis were directly related to the techniques I learned in
the operations research course, while inventory management was related to the
manufacturing course. The subject of inventory management was quite interesting to me
because it was a topic that affected all stages of supply chain operations. The most
challenging part was ensuring the accuracy of the data in the shipment records, because
even a small mistake could negatively affect stock levels and order fulfillment and restart the
entire process. To prevent this, it is tracked both manually and in the system, and products
are counted repeatedly if necessary, which is one of the processes that complicates these
operations.
First of all, this internship introduced me to a sector that I was previously quite distant from
and showed me how enjoyable, dynamic and open-ended the sector was and how important
an operation experience I gained. It was a month that I was very involved with Excel and
really tried to learn logistics in all its details. I gained in-depth knowledge about warehouse
management and operational processes. I especially observed how important the
warehouse layout and new shelving systems were in increasing the efficiency of operations.
The new shelving system allowed products to be found more easily and processed quickly,
which was a very important development both in terms of time management and labor
efficiency, and the fact that this layout was made thanks to my project motivated me even
more. I also worked on how products were placed on the shelves, which products waited in
stock for how long, and the optimization of these processes, and I interpreted and visualized
these studies clearly on Excel. During this process, I learned how important it is to regularly
control stock entries and exits, especially in controlling the expiration dates of products, and
that in addition to weight, size and stock, expiration dates are also important in the shelving
system. Paying attention to the expiration date of products, especially for Mondelez, plays a
critical role in terms of customer satisfaction and preventing losses. Another important
detail I learned during my internship was how sales of certain products change seasonally.
As a result of the analyses I made, I noticed that especially candy and chocolate products
were sold more in certain months. For example, candy showed a significant increase during
religious holidays, while I observed that chocolate sales increased especially in September.
This data would be an important reference for future sales forecasts and stock management.
Thanks to these experiences, I better understood the importance of warehouse
organization, stock control and sales trends in workflow. I had the chance to put the
information I learned theoretically into practice in operational processes.

The engineering activity that I observed and was a part of during my internship was a racking
system optimization aimed at more efficient placement of products in the warehouse and
improvement of stock management. This project aimed to make the placement of products
11

and stock control processes faster, more accurate and systematic, and shortened the
operation time, provided energy efficiency and reduced costs.
The main task I had to do was to review the existing shelf system within the warehouse
layout and create a new shelf layout plan. In this context:
- Placing the products according to demand intensity,
- Separating the products into specific areas according to their expiration dates,
- It was planned to position the shelves according to the distance to the shipping area in a
way that would reduce time loss during loading and unloading processes.
- The weight of the products and the area they cover were also taken into consideration
during all this planning.
During the internship process, I observed that placing products that are particularly in high
demand and run out in a short time closer to the pick points both saved time and allowed
for more efficient use of labor.
The main performance indicators and observations taken into consideration during this
process were as follows:
- Warehouse processing times: The times when products enter and exit the warehouse were
measured. After the shelf arrangement, it was observed that there was no shortening of the
processing time with pickers and forklifts, especially for frequently sold products, but there
was a shortening in the part where they go to the shipping area with the new shelf system.
- Stock accuracy: Thanks to the new shelf system, the placement of products in the right
places and the acceleration of stock controls increased stock accuracy. While this process
was carried out via devices called RF and SAP in Nestle operations, it was carried out as Excel
and manual entry in Mondelez operations.
- Workforce efficiency: Optimizing the shelf layout shortened the times when employees
found and placed products, thus increasing the efficiency of the workforce.
Analysis and Problematic Issues
As a result of all the observations made, it was determined that the part where engineers
and blue-collar employees working in the operation had the most problems was spending
too much time, the best-selling products on the shelves being far from the shipping points
and in irrelevant places, and empty pallets being in irrelevant places. The lack of correctly
positioned pick points was a situation that slowed down the operation.
It was observed that products on the shelves should be sorted according to their expiration
date, weight, and order density, but this practice was not done systematically, and some
products were randomly placed according to the gaps on the shelves. As a result, it was
highlighted that some products could not be sold on time during certain periods, and this
situation caused excess stock, empty pallets, and shelves.
With the data I received from the warehouse management system (WMS), I concluded that
inefficiencies in warehouse layout extended order fulfillment times. To correct this situation,
I designed a project to implement a regional picking strategy that would reduce unnecessary
movements of employees and make the picking process more fluid.
12

Warehouse Shelving System Optimization
The engineering activity that I observed and actively participated in during my internship
was to optimize the shelf system and product placement of the storage Mondelez in the
warehouse. This project that I focused on aimed to increase the speed and efficiency of
warehouse operations.
Detailed Description of the Project
As part of this project, I periodically analyzed the order quantities of the products given to
me in Excel. As a result of this analysis, I determined which products received more orders in
certain periods. After examining the order quantities and periodic changes, I created a
warehouse map that shows which shelves the products in the warehouse were located on. I
added the order quantities to the map and visualized the areas where the orders were
concentrated with a colored map using conditional formatting. In this way, I was able to
determine which shelves had the most picking operations.
Figure 10: Location of products in the warehouse before editing on Excel
As a result, I observed that the areas where the picking operations were most concentrated
were far from the pick points and shipping areas. To solve this situation, I developed a new
shelf layout proposal that suggested placing products with high order volumes in more easily
accessible points. In this project , I used the information in Chapter 6 of the Warehouse &
Distribution Science book.
Performance and Data
The key performance indicators I considered during this activity were as follows:
- Picking Time: I analyzed the picking time of high-demand products with the current layout.
I noticed that this time took an average of 20% longer during peak order periods.
- Order Accuracy: It was observed that the current shelving system caused confusion and
that some orders were picked incorrectly.
- Labor Efficiency: I observed that employees spent more time in the warehouse due to the
messy shelving layout, and this situation reduced labor efficiency to a certain extent.
13

Figure 11: Excel worksheet that I worked in about detail of the products
Current Problematic Issues
Based on the data I analyzed, I determined that one of the biggest problems in the
warehouse layout was that products in high demand were positioned far from picking and
shipping points. This situation both extended processing times and caused employees to
exert extra effort. In addition, the disorder between the shelves caused orders to get mixed
up and the wrong products to be picked.
Points Requiring Improvement and Alternative Solution Suggestions
In this context, the need to restructure the shelf layout emerged. Moving products in high
demand to more strategic locations within the warehouse and bringing them closer to the
picking points could speed up the process. After developing this proposal, I reviewed the
relevant literature and examined different approaches to picking time optimization and
warehouse layout design. I learned that systems called slotting, where products are placed
according to demand density, are successful in such warehouse operations. As a result of
this literature review, I evaluated that the slotting method is applicable to make the shelf
layout I suggested more effective.

3.Conclusions
During my time at DHL Supply Chain, I gained a lot of experience in observing how things work
in the logistics sector and understanding both the theoretical and practical operations of the
sector. During this time, I was worked in the logistics processes of Mondelez International.
Activities I Performed During the Internship
14

During the internship, I took part in every stage of logistics operations. By analyzing storage
processes, I observed how products were accepted, stored and collected in line with orders,
and from time to time I took part in this process. I was involved in projects to increase the
efficiency of these processes. In particular, I worked on a project to optimize the layout of the
most demanded products in the warehouse. Within this scope, I analyzed the order density
of the products and suggested that those in high demand be moved to shelves closer to the
shipping point and pick points. I prepared various reports using Excel and data analysis tools
and presented these reports.It was how large and how logistics processes serve more than
one area. I realized that a logistics operation does not only mean that products leave the
warehouse and reach the customer, but also that every stage of this process requires detailed
analysis and optimization. Analyzing and reporting data using Excel and showing how
operations can be improved has been one of the most important professional gains of mine.
Industrial engineers and other technical teams working at DHL were constantly taking an
active role in the field to ensure that operations proceed smoothly. Observing the engineers'
efforts to make continuous improvements in areas such as warehouse layout planning,
inventory management and demand forecasting was inspiring for me and I think this is one of
the most enjoyable aspects of our profession. In addition, taking part in every stage to bridge
the gap between field operations and technical operations has added a lot to me.
Current Status of the Logistics Sector and the Challenges It Faces
Logistics is a fastly growing and increasingly complex sector in the world. Along with growth,
there are various challenges. An example of this is increasing customer expectations. Fast
delivery demands and multi-channel distribution networks increase the complexity of
operational processes. The sector also struggles with uncertainties regarding locations of
customers. DHL must and continue to invest in digital technologies and continuously improve
their processes to meet these challenges.
Figure 12: Digitalization targets
Changes in the Industry in the Future
In the next years, artificial intelligence, big data analytics, the Internet of Things (IoT) and
autonomous vehicle technologies will come to the forefront, as in every industry. This will
reduce logistics costs and shorten delivery times. Artificial intelligence will play a major role,
especially in demand forecasting, route optimization and warehouse management. From a
15

sustainability perspective, it is essential to increase initiatives to reduce the carbon footprint,
because logistics is a sector that has a very negative impact on the world in terms of energy
consumption, packaging waste and manpower and must be intervened.

a. Impact
During my internship at DHL Supply Chain, my observations allowed me to see how the
logistics sector can create global, economic, environmental and social impacts.
Global Impact: Optimization in logistics affects international trade in terms of cost and
operational speed. During my internship, the project I carried out to increase the efficiency
of the storage and distribution of Mondelez products, as well as the inspection teams and
customers from European countries, helped me to observe and make this conclusion.
Economic Impact: Of course, improving storage and shipping processes is one of the parts
that increase the profit margins of companies the most. The solution based on the new shelf
layout and intensive collection areas can help reduce operational costs and ensure that
products are in the right place at the right time. This increases customer satisfaction and
also increases the company's competitiveness.
Environmental Impact: Every environmental project carried out in logistics operations will be
very effective because waste and energy spent are at a very high level. More effective
planning can help reduce carbon emissions, which in turn reduces the environmental impact
of the logistics sector.
Figure 13: Decarbonization targets
Social Impact: Ensuring that products reach customers faster means better service. Delivery
processes, especially for basic consumer goods and food products, definitely increase social
benefits.

b. Teamwork
During my internship, teamwork played a key role in the success of logistics operations.
While working at DHL Gebze Warehouse 8, I had the opportunity to collaborate with people
from various fields of expertise and observe team dynamics. I worked particularly with the
operations manager, shift manager, stock control officer and warehouse workers.
My operations manager is responsible for the overall management of daily processes and
supervised the efficiency of the Mondelez International operations in Warehouse 8. The
shift manager managed the distribution of tasks among the teams within the warehouse,
ensuring that daily operations proceeded smoothly. The stock control officer have an
important role in the layout of the products and stock tracking. The products receiving,
storage, order preparation and shipping teams ensured product movements within the
warehouse.
I analyzed the warehouse layout and order picking processes. and the data to identify areas
where picking operations were particularly intense and suggested a more effective
warehouse layout plan. During the internship, each team member contributed in their own
area of expertise and ensured that the operations flows successfully. This team work greatly
contributed to the development of me and also my manager's suggestions for making
warehouse operations more efficient.
As a result, operational changes were achieved balanced use of expertise and collaboration
within the team. With this process and my experience help me to understanding how
important of the teamwork and how different engineers can work together efficiently.

c. Self-directed Learning

During my internship at DHL Supply Chain, I realized that learning on my own was very
important. The fast-moving logistics environment showed me that I needed to be active in
finding new information and improving my skills. I saw that I needed more knowledge about
things like warehouse management, logistics processes, and data analysis to be more helpful
in my tasks.
At the beginning, I noticed that I didn’t fully understand how to design a good warehouse
layout or how the order picking process worked. To improve, I started reading the book
*Warehouse & Distribution Science*, which helped me learn more about the theory behind
warehouse design and inventory movement. I then tried to connect what I read to what I
saw in the warehouse. For example, I used tools like Excel’s pivot tables and conditional
formatting to analyze the data I gathered. This helped me identify areas in the warehouse
where workers could be used more effectively, especially in busy parts of the order picking
process.
My main goal was to understand logistics better so I could make suggestions that would
really make a difference. I didn’t just rely on what I saw at work — I also did research on
topics like artificial intelligence, data analytics, and the Internet of Things (IoT) to see how
these new technologies could improve warehouse management. I learned how AI could help
predict future demand or how IoT could track products in the warehouse in real time. This
research gave me a better understanding of how the warehouse could use new technologies
to work more efficiently.
Talking to my colleagues was also a big part of my learning process. I asked for feedback
from the warehouse manager, the shift manager, and other team members to make sure I
was on the right track. Their advice helped me see the logistics process more clearly and
made my ideas better. For example, when I shared my suggestions about warehouse layout,
their comments helped me think about whether my ideas would actually work in the real
world.
One important thing I learned is that combining theory and real-world experience is key. I
could learn a lot from books and online resources, but I also needed to understand the day-
to-day challenges from the people working in the warehouse. By listening to them, I
adjusted my ideas to make sure they were realistic and useful.
Overall, this internship showed me that learning on my own is important, not just for now,
but for my future career. The logistics field is always changing, and I learned that if I want to
keep up, I have to keep learning about new technologies and market trends. This experience
helped me grow both personally and professionally. I now know that self-learning is not only
about improving my work performance but also about being ready for future challenges.
Whether through studying or learning from others, I understand that continuous learning is
the key to success.
